entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French exciter, from Latin excitare, from ex- + citare to rouse cite

def.dt: :to rouse to an emotional response scenes to excite the hardest man to pity
:to arouse (as a strong emotional response) by appropriate stimuli excite enthusiasm for the new regime Arthur Knight
:to produce a magnetic field in excite a dynamo
:to increase the activity of (as a living organism) :stimulate
:to raise (as an atomic nucleus, an atom, or a molecule) to a higher energy level
